Tah was billed as the first domino, as it were, even though Bayern have already added to their ranks at centre-back this summer. One silver lining for United, perhaps, is that a club as well run as Bayern will have more irons in the fire, which ought to come to light pretty quickly.

"They have certainly made it pretty clear that De Ligt has no long-term future at the Allianz Arena. A U-turn on that transfer stance in the short-term shouldn't fool the Dutchman into thinking different. He must push for a departure."

PSG are increasingly likely to sign Jadon Sancho this summer. That's according to Football Insider - amid continued speculation over the former Borussia Dortmund player - with United preparing to take a significant financial loss on their £72.9million recruit. Sancho is back in the fold at Old Trafford. He might even start in the Community Shield due to injuries.

headline: Community Shield security latest ahead of Manchester United vs Man City amid UK riots
body: Manchester United and the FA are adopting a business as usual approach to the Community Shield at Wembley, amid widespread riots and chaos around the United Kingdom.

Disorder around the UK has increased over the last week and prime minister Sir Keir Starmer has condemned the riots, promising those involved would face 'the full force of the law'. Greater Manchester have arrested 28 people allegedly involved in rioting across Manchester last weekend and the Mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, released a statement on Wednesday morning to speak out against different locations in London being targeted by protestors.

Thousands of United and Manchester City fans will descend onto London on Saturday for the Community Shield at Wembley and some may have concerns about disorder. However, United are approaching the fixture with a business-as-usual approach and club sources have said their security plans remain watertight ahead of the Community Shield.

Sources elsewhere have confirmed the FA are not aware of any threats to the safety of fans attending Wembley, or to local residents in the area, in the build-up to the game. At present, it's understood there is no intel of any planned marches or demonstrations, but the FA are working closely with the police and local authorities should any further information arise.

It has also been reiterated that in line with all events at Wembley, the safety and security of fans and spectators is of paramount importance. The national stadium's rules outline a zero-tolerance policy for any form of anti-social, offensive and discriminatory conduct, and anyone found guilty of this behaviour will be ejected from the stadium and reported to the authorities. United, the FA and Wembley are expecting a trouble-free occasion and that should ease any concerns for Manchester-based supporters who are travelling to the game.

The Community Shield is contested by the FA Cup and Premier League winners, and United are looking to claim another victory over City after their stunning 2-1 win in May. Alejandro Garnacho and Kobbie Mainoo were on the scoresheet in the FA Cup final and both youngsters returned to Carrington earlier this week ahead of the Community Shield.

headline: Man United icon Cristiano Ronaldo shows true colours as former teammate confirms retirement
body: Cristiano Ronaldo has sent an emotional message to former Real Madrid and Portugal teammate Pepe after his retirement was announced. The 41-year-old centre-back called time on an immense two-decade playing career on Thursday.

"I want to thank God for giving me the wisdom to be able to continue my journey," he said in a video posted online. "I can't help but also thank all the presidents who bet and believed in me to be able to perform my work.

"To all the employees of all the clubs I've been to, who are the soul and essence of the clubs and the national team. And I want to thank everyone in the background. I want to leave a thank you and a hug of gratitude for all of you. And thank you all very much."

Having first featured on a pitch together in 2007 during a Euro 2008 qualifying game for Portugal, the pair went on to play 348 times in the same team. 107 of those were for their country, with the last game of Pepe's career being the penalty shootout defeat to France earlier this summer at Euro 2024 in the quarter-finals.

The bulk of matches was at Real Madrid though. where Pepe played 334 times in total, scoring 15 times and winning the Champions League on three occasions. With Ronaldo he played 241 times for Los Blancos during a glittering period.

Taking to social media to wish his compatriot well, Ronaldo wrote: "There are not enough words to express how much you mean to me, friend. We won everything there was to win on the field, but the greatest achievement is the friendship and respect I have for you. You are unique, my brother. Thank you for so much.

In a statement of their own, Pepe's former club said "he was one of the best Real Madrid defenders and one of the best in European football," adding, "and he will always have the recognition and affection of all Real Madrid fans. Real Madrid would like to wish him and his family the best of luck in this new stage of his life."
Ronaldo himself is 39 but continues to play for club and country, now running out for Al-Nassr in Saudi Arabia. Pepe ended his club career at Porto, where he started out as a boy.

headline: Manchester United player set to stay amid transfer interest
body: Manchester United defender Will Fish has suffered torn ligaments and is set to be sidelined for up to five weeks.
Fish came on at half-time in the 3-0 friendly defeat to Liverpool in South Carolina on Saturday but was carried off injured after committing a foul.

United manager Erik ten Hag walked onto the pitch to check on Fish’s well-being and it is understood he had a scan on his return to United’s Carrington training complex on Monday. Sources say Fish did not suffer a fracture and the prognosis is better than Fish had expected.
The setback all but rules out a transfer for Fish, who has generated interest from Championship clubs. The 21-year-old's contract expires next year but United have the option of an additional year.

Before the injury, Fish was told he would not be sold unless there was another incoming at centre half due to new signing Leny Yoro’s fractured metatarsal that could rule him out until November. United sold centre back Willy Kambwala last month and released Raphael Varane.

headline: 'Too much' - Paul Scholes feels Manchester United have dodged £50m transfer bullet
body: Paul Scholes believes Manchester United have dodged a bullet by walking away from potentially signing Amadou Onana from Everton.

The 22-year-old had been strongly linked with a move to Old Trafford with Erik ten Hag keen to bolster his midfield to help ahead of another title push. However, Onana completed the £50million move to Aston Villa instead, putting pen-to-paper on a five-year deal.

He has big boots to fill following the exit of Douglas Luiz who was the long-standing maestro of the team before joining Juventus. The Belgium international, who is highly-rated, played every minute of their Euro 2024 campaign before they were knocked out to France in the round-of-16.
However, United legend Scholes believes Villa overpaid for Onana's services and was pleased to see his former club did not oblige to Everton's demands.

"He [Luiz] had to go for financial reasons and I think he'll be a big miss. I thought he was brilliant for them," Scholes said during The Overlap'slatest fan debate. "Now it's who comes in to replace him?"

"I don't really see the Onana thing either. I didn't see it while he was at Everton, I didn't see it at Belgium either. When they said £50m for him I just thought: 'ooh, that sounds a little bit too much'.

"Look, [Unai] Emery being the manager that he is, he might get something out of him. It might be a club that suits him - I don't know. But, where I'm stood now, £50m for him just seems like a lot of money."

Meanwhile, Liverpool legend Jamie Carragher who sat alongside Scholes, added: "I was never really impressed with him much at Everton. I thought he was alright when I saw him for Belgium, maybe its a different style of football as well, but it will be interesting to see if he can replace Douglas Luiz in there."

headline: Dan Ashworth has explained Man United Sander Berge transfer interest despite critics
body: Manchester United's transfer link to Burnley midfielder Sander Berge has left supporters above boiling point. A quick scan across social media and YouTube, you will come across hundreds of points why United shouldn't sign him.

Berge, 26, emerged as one of United's midfield transfer targets this week after they reportedly decided to withdraw their interest in Paris Saint-Germain star Manuel Ugarte. However, after suffering two relegations from the Premier League with Sheffield United and Burnley, doubts over his ability to perform at the top of English football have flooded any positivity.

One point that is a constant on social media is the lack of suitors for his services. For example, when Leicester City were relegated in 2023, at least three teams wanted to sign James Maddison. When Southampton went down, James Ward-Prowse's move to West Ham came after the likes of Tottenham were keen.

It's believed among the fanbase that Berge would be viewed as a 'panic signing' - despite the window not closing for over 20 days - yet the recruitment team at Old Trafford are seemingly testing the water with Burnley's resolve. According to reports, talks are underway with the Championship side over a potential deal.

Under new sporting director Dan Ashworth, who is taking the lead of United's transfer business, it's hardly a surprise that he is on their radar. When Ashworth was at Newcastle, he attempted to bring the Norwegian to St James' Park at the start of 2023.

“I was prepared to go and play a cup match, first and foremost, and was looking forward to it. I had visitors and people would come and watch a match. It didn’t turn out that way and I was told that I was not part of the squad.

“Then it was a bit like that back and forth. The club and my agents tried to see what was possible to achieve. There was interest there. It never got to the point where I needed to make a choice. I wasn’t very involved. It passed, then I was playing matches again. There will be speculation. The boys know how to make a bit of fun out of it.

“I see that it can look like that from the outside, that it will be the same pattern every time, but I don’t stress,” Berge added. “Teammates and people around joke a bit about it when it comes up again and again, but for me it’s just about focusing on football.”

headline: Erik ten Hag must start favourite two Manchester United players for first time in four months
body: How good will it be to see Luke Shaw and Lisandro Martinez starting together on Saturday?
The pair last started together when Manchester United played West Ham at Old Trafford on February 4, a game that was marred by Martinez picking up another injury.

He sustained an injury to the medial collateral ligament in his knee and returned for the final home game of the league season, but Shaw was ruled out for the remainder of the campaign two weeks after the West Ham victory when suffering an injury against Luton Town.

Both Martinez and Shaw missed large parts of last season and their respective absences at different periods were undoubtedly a factor in the team's spectacular regression. They are left-footed players who are crucial in build-up play.

“We have missed him [in] every game because he brings a composure in the team and a calmness in the team and, at the same time, a winning attitude," said Ten Hag when about Martinez's absence last season. He can express this very clearly, he can transfer that to the team and that contributes to our levels.”

He continued: "It's not an advantage. Everyone knows my philosophy, to have Licha Martinez and Luke Shaw, two left-footed [defenders]. Also, we haven't had Tyrell Malacia available. So all the way, all the time this season, we have to make compromises. And that is not in our advantage. But today we managed it and hopefully it's not too bad with Luke.”

If you asked Ten Hag which two players he wouldn't want to lose for a prolonged period due to injury in a campaign, there's a high chance he would say Martinez and Shaw. Martinez was outstanding in his first season after signing from Ajax, setting the tone in the dressing room and on the pitch, and his passing ability makes him a unique option.

Shaw is also one of the finest left-backs in Europe when he's fit and at his best, although unfortunately, he struggled to maintain a clean bill of health throughout 2023/24. The new season is a clean slate and Martinez and Shaw must stay fit. They are two of Ten Hag's favourite players and their campaign should start at Wembley on Saturday when United take on Manchester City in the Community Shield.

Shaw was asked about his injuries at the beginning of June and said: “No one knows the situation, what’s been happening. Obviously, I think people have seen that there was a setback, but I was actually very close to returning to team training. I think it was the day before.

“In my opinion, I was pushing to try and get back for the games and the final and I think I pushed too hard. I came back too quick and I actually ended up getting another injury in my hamstring, which was a (grade) 2c. That was three weeks from the final and they said it was a six-week injury, so that’s obviously why there was that setback.

“I think people have been getting confused with what’s actually happened because nothing had ever been said. That’s why I did my post. I got a few people coming up to me, saying, ‘how can you not be fit for United and (can) for England?’

“But the circumstances were that I did push to do everything I can to be fit for United, and that’s been really my whole season. It’s been disappointing for me, but I want to do everything I can, first and foremost, for United.

“That’s my club, I’ve been there for a long time but, of course, that wasn’t the case, so that was hard to obviously take in the last few weeks. But I’m here now and I’m still not there yet, I’ve still got a while to go, but I’m trying to do everything I can to make it happen.”

There is evidence Shaw was perhaps mishandled by the medical staff last season. That cannot happen again because United's fortunes this term could hinge on whether the club's longest-serving player and Martinez stay fit and avoid injury, such is their importance to the team.
United fans will be delighted to see Martinez and Shaw's names on the starting team sheet on Saturday if they get the nod to face City in the Community Shield.

headline: Shaw return, Zirkzee spark, Garnacho battle - How Man United can get best out of Marcus Rashford
body: One of the biggest issues facing Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag is how he gets the best out of Marcus Rashford.

After an incredible 2022/23 season which yielded 30 goals in all competitions, it was expected that Rashford would lead United in Ten Hag's second season to really challenge Man City, Arsenal and Liverpool.
But United fell from fourth place to eighth place and it wasn't helped by a huge downturn in Rashford's form which ended in him being snubbed for the England squad for EURO 2024.

The 26-year-old managed just eight goals in all competitions last term and those numbers simply have to improve if United want to improve their league position and, on a personal level, if he is to force his way back into the England squad.

But how does Ten Hag go about doing that? Greater support in his current role with new signings? A formation change? A positional change? Or does he need to leave United to truly thrive? MEN Sport writers have offered their view ahead of a crucial season in Rashford's career.

Rashford's exploits in 2022/23 demonstrated that United have a world-class player on their hands when he is at the peak of his powers. He was outstanding in Erik ten Hag's first season at the club, scoring 30 goals in a single season for the first time in his career.
He oozed confidence and he looked like scoring every time he got in and around the penalty area. Much of his good fortune stemmed from his relationship with Luke Shaw down United's left side.

The England duo had a terrific understanding of each other's traits, with Shaw often bombing forward on the overlap when Rashford ventured inside on his stronger right foot. United, however, were denied that combination all too often last season because of the former's injury issues.

However, Shaw has now worked his way back to full fitness and will be determined to avoid a repeat of last season's frustrations. February's 4-3 win over Wolves at Molineux, particularly in the first half, provided enough evidence to showcase how much more effective Rashford is when he is partnered down the left with his fellow countryman.
If Shaw can maintain his fitness, that will go a long way towards helping Rashford reach his best levels. Fingers crossed.

If United are to have a successful season then it is pretty clear they need Rashford firing at the levels of 2022/23. He was United's most important player as they won the Carabao Cup, reached the FA Cup final and qualified for the Champions League.

Yes, injuries hurt United last season but Rashford's downturn in form did not help either. What he needs is consistent games out on the left-wing, a consistent side playing alongside him to help him thrive, and, crucially, Luke Shaw remaining fit at left-back.
Rashford and Shaw have enjoyed a successful relationship at both club and international level but he managed just 12 Premier League appearances because of injuries last term.
Compare that to 31 appearances the season prior and it is clear to see the benefit Rashford receives from playing with his preferred partner on the left-hand side.

The signing of Joshua Zirkzee should help United get the best out of Rashford to start this season. Despite standing at 6ft 4in, he calls himself a "false striker" and a nine-and-a-half, tending to drop into midfield rather than always leading the line.

Doing so should provide the space for Rashford to push ahead of Zirkzee, as he has previously done when playing alongside Harry Kane for England and did so well during the FA Cup final. Bruno Fernandes was the 'false nine' that day, and signing Zirkzee should allow Erik ten Hag to play that way more often, especially with Rasmus Hojlund missing the start of the season.

Beginning the campaign with Fernandes or Jadon Sancho potentially deployed as the furthest player forward would be the best way to set up Rashford for success. After using Sancho there last pre-season, Ten Hag started Rashford in that role once the competitive games came around.
The manager cannot revert to that if he wants to get the best out of his player. Ten Hag has to accept that Rashford is no longer as effective as he once was as a number nine.

Marcus Rashford must put the underwhelming season he had last term behind him and look to reproduce the heights he did during the 2022/23 campaign. As one of the most important players in the United squad, his contribution will be key to United having a successful season this year.

It's clear to see that injuries to Luke Shaw last season had a major impact in the squad and consequently meant that Rashford netted just seven goals in 33 Premier League games. Both have enjoyed a successful spell at Old Trafford and Shaw's absence played a part in the team's lack of goals as well as it being their their worst finish (eighth) in 34 years.
Having recently returned to full fitness, Shaw is expected to play a key role to ensure a repeat of last season is avoided.
Rashford has plenty to offer Manchester United still. A player who scored 30 goals just over a year ago doesn't become bad overnight.

It's not all positional for Rashford either, it seems that there are conditions that have to be met off the field to get the best out of him. He is a complex character who needs to fit in and feel the love of his coach. When that lacks, and the environment as a whole turns sour, he doesn't offer his best.

That often comes from the left though. Rashford has not been a natural striker for a while and with two No.9s signed in the past year for over £100million combined, it indicates that he won't be played their much. Competition on the left is strong with Alejandro Garnacho, but Rashford is a flexible player.

When cutting in and playing on transition he has all the weapons to be a dangerous forward. If things function around him, perhaps with a fit full-back or a non-vacant midfield, then there is reason to think he can get back to being the threat he has been before. Rashford has so much still to give that it is too soon right him off.

The frustration around Marcus Rashford last season arose from what came before. The forward plundered 30 goals in 2022/2023 and that's not to mention the three that came for England at the World Cup in Qatar that very winter. At his absolute best, the Academy graduate is capable of single-handedly winning matches, and being the talisman that Erik ten Hag needs for United to propel themselves back into the top-four positions.

For all the tactical or personnel tweaks the manager can make, though, getting Rashford back to tip-top form, like so many other players, must come from within. The 26-year-old has to re-find that spark himself.

Only then will it really matter how, where and with whom he's deployed. Being re-united with Luke Shaw will help, so too having competition for his place - new and old - but it's not so much about how United can strive to get the best out of Rashford as how can Rashford revive himself for United.

headline: Toney £40m deal, Rashford reality, Sancho decision - Man United's dream front threes
body: Manchester United are still reportedly hopeful of securing a deal for Brentford's £40million-rated striker Ivan Toney, who could significantly alter Erik ten Hag's attacking otions.

Toney, 28, is in the final year of his contract with Brentford, and it's believed the club would be open to negotiations around the £40million mark. The England international has been frequently linked with a move to Old Trafford, although United's decision to spend £36m on Bologna striker Joshua Zirkzee in July seemed to have ended their interest.

However, it soon became apparent that United were keen to sign another forward during the summer transfer window, a need which has intensified since Rasmus Hojlund was recently sidelined for the first few weeks of the season, leaving Zirkzee as the only senior option up front. Due to his participation in Euro 2024 for the Netherlands, the Dutchman didn't play in any of United's pre-season friendlies and is unlikely to start in Saturday's Community Shield match against Manchester City.

This leaves Ten Hag with limited options for now, but if United can secure Toney, there are several ways they could set up for the 2024-25 Premier League season. We look at what Ten Hag's ideal front three might look like - and more options.

Jadon Sancho has endured a rather inconsistent career at Old Trafford, but this season could feel like a fresh start for him. After making up with Ten Hag following his contribution to Borussia Dortmund's Champions League final run during his loan spell, he is eager to establish himself as a regular at United, three years after his initial arrival.

His playing style would nicely complement Marcus Rashford's more straightforward approach on the left wing. Rashford is keen to silence his critics after also missing out on Euro 2024, just like Sancho.

Neither of them have played alongside Toney before, but the Brentford talisman's physical presence in the centre would allow Rashford and Sancho to make runs behind and benefit from flick-ons and Toney's renowned hold-up play.
Nothing excites Old Trafford more than a winger swiftly charging down the wings, so why not two?

Alejandro Garnacho was one of Ten Hag's most frequently used players last season, and it's hard to believe he's still only 20. He certainly deserves a starting spot and could even challenge Rashford on the left flank if Sancho - or either Amad or Antony - is chosen on the right.

Despite their disappointing 2023-24 campaign, scoring goals wasn't the biggest issue for United when these three players were on the pitch together. The challenge for Ten Hag was injuries, prompting him to seek two new strikers to ease the load off Hojlund.
At just 21, the Danish player could benefit from teaming up with the more seasoned Toney, who has also proven his ability to make a significant impact as a substitute for England.

Throughout most of Ten Hag's tenure, he has favoured a 4-2-3-1 formation, with two wingers supporting a single striker. However, last season saw the former Ajax manager occasionally employ a 4-4-2 diamond both in and out of possession, with Bruno Fernandes sometimes taking on the No. 9 role and Scott McTominay sitting slightly deeper, such as in May's FA Cup final victory.

Considering that Zirkzee recently confessed to being a "nine-and-a-half", why not play him alongside Toney (or Hojlund) with Fernandes orchestrating the game from behind? Both Mason Mount and Kobbie Mainoo possess the all-round skills to function as shuttling midfielders, and McTominay has previously played this role under Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.
This formation would also provide Casemiro with additional cover in the No. 6 position ahead of what is expected to be a pivotal season for many at Old Trafford.

headline: Sander Berge's four-year transfer disaster is perfect reason for Man United to confirm £51m deal
body: It's fair to say that Manchester United's search for a new No.6 hasn't exactly gone to plan. Following the early decision not to make Sofyan Amrabat's loan permanent, United's attempt at signing a new midfielder before the start of the 2024/25 season is hanging by a thread.

For some time, Paris Saint-Germain star Manuel Ugarte was the leading candidate to move to Old Trafford. With personal terms not thought to be a problem, the Ligue 1 club's asking price of £51million (€60m) has proved to be a stumbling block with reports claiming that the club have withdrawn their interest for now.

Alternatives are now being looked at and over the last 24 hours, a list of new names have emerged. Amid talk of the highly-rated Real Sociedad star Martin Zubimendi and AS Monaco's Youssouf Fofana, a surprise link for Burnley's Sander Berge has left some bamboozled.

Berge, 26, has spent the last three-and-a-half seasons in England at Sheffield United and Burnley. The Blades paid £22m for Berge's services in January 2020 after his impressive performances in Belgium before he moved to Turf Moor for just £12m last August.

He recorded a third relegation from the Premier League with Burnley last term, prompting many to already throw shade over his possible arrival at Old Trafford. If reports are to be believed, United face paying up to £30m for Berge this summer.

In today's market, which sees clubs forced to pay a premium for players despite concerns over Financial Fair Play rules, it's not quite clear why United would even entertain Burnley's valuation. First of all, let's consider his defensive statistics. According to FBRef, the Norway international ranks in the top 91st percentile for aerials won and 83rd percentile for completed passes compared to positional peers in Europe's Big 5 leagues.

Compared to Ugarte, Berge completed more passes per 90 minutes, more shot-creating actions and boasts a better tackling success rate. However, as a No.6, Ugarte is simply better. The Uruguay international attempted and won more tackles, made more interceptions and won more tackles in the three different areas of the pitch.

Certain mitigating factors do determine these stats such as Burnley's constant battle at the bottom of the Premier League compared to PSG's dominance in France. However, taking Ugarte out of it completely, there's a problem with Berge that United simply can't overlook.

Joshua Zirkzee and Leny Yoro, United's first two signings this summer, both represent quality at a young age alongside promising future market value. For many years, the club has overpaid for players and lost millions on them when the time came to depart - Paul Pogba, Donny van de Beek, Antony Martial and many more.

When Berge emerged as one of Scandavia's brightest talents at Genk after three years in Belgium, he was valued at £18.9m (€22m) by Transfermarkt. Unbelievably, that figure has never increased. In fact, at the end of his second season at Sheffield United (2022), his market value had fallen to £13.7m (€16m).

After winning promotion back to the Premier League in 2020, it increased slightly to £17m (€20m), where it remains now. That is £13m less than the reported £30m that Burnley are demanding for the midfielder this summer.

That means that since seeing his market value fly from £7.7m to £18.9m at Genk, Berge's merit in the transfer market has dropped across the last four years. On the other hand, Ugarte's market value has only risen since his breakthrough in Europe.

When he signed for Sporting CP in 2021, he was valued at £5.1m (€6m), two years later he brought in over £50m. Before PSG's clear stance of wanting away with him, his value reached £51.5m, the figure that the French giants are holding out for.
That has to be something that United bear in mind in their pursuit for a new No.6.

headline: Man United transfer would be disastrous and must be avoided as Manuel Ugarte alternative emerges
body: Manchester United are just days away from facing rivals Manchester City in the Community Shield.

Erik ten Hag's side will face their first major challenge of 2024/25 against Pep Guardiola's side on Saturday before kicking off their Premier League campaign less than a week later against Fulham. Joshua Zirkzee and and Leny Yoro are the only new arrivals at Old Trafford so far this summer with the latter out of action for three months through injury.

And there will be some concern that United's midfield has not been strengthened with the ageing Casemiro set to start against City at Wembley. Below are some of the latest media reports surrounding United as well as a view on each one...
Manchester United are said to be preparing to hijack AC Milan's move for Monaco midfielder Youssouf Fofana. The Ligue 1 club are said to be holding out for a fee in the region of €35 million (£30m).

And Italian journalist Fabrizio Biasin writes in his Tutto Mercato round-up of the latest transfer news that Milan are getting closer to a move for Fofana. The Frenchman scored four goals and provided four assists in 32 Ligue 1 appearances last season.

MEN Sport's Isaac Seelochan says: Youssouf Fofana mainly plays as a central midfielder rather than in defensive midfield, which needs to be United's priority. But he can still be used in that position and if United are looking for someone who can cover the entire midfield then Fofana may be a smart signing.

However, aged 25 and having never played outside of France, there has to be a question mark over whether he can make the step up to the Premier League. Manual Ugarte is likely to be a better signing but that deal looks to be off.

Italian outlet Tutto Mercato also claim that Erik ten Hag is in favour of Sofyan Amrabat returning to the club. It is said that United have not completely killed off the idea of signing Amrabat, who spent last season on loan at Old Trafford.
it is claimed that signing Amrabat will be a backup option if United fail to land a new midfielder.

That area of the pitch is almost as important as signing a new defender and the club cannot afford to get another season with Casemiro and Amrabat in defensive midfield.

headline: Man United star Bruno Fernandes shows true colours with one-word demand to teammate
body: Bruno Fernandes has been pushing his Manchester United teammates to their limits since returning to training this pre-season.

Fernandes, 29, reported back to Carrington on Friday alongside Alejandro Garnacho, Altay Bayindir and Diogo Dalot. They joined Joshua Zirkzee, who got to work at the start of last week and have since welcomed Facundo Pellistri, Lisandro Martinez, Luke Shaw and Kobbie Mainoo.

Now, on Wednesday, footage of Fernandes motivating members of the squad during their gym sessions has been shared on social media by the club. The video begins with Bayindir ready to use the chest press machine, with his captain in close attendance.
READ MORE:Frenkie De Jong has already made feelings clear on United transfer
READ MORE:Noussair Mazraoui sends one-word message as United transfer wait continues
As the goalkeeper is bracing himself, Fernandes offers some words of encouragement. "Come on," he tells his teammate before slapping Bayindir on the chest as he is about to start working out.
Fernandes then starts shouting "Push!" several times as the Turkiye international gradually lifts the weight. Bayindir eventually completes the repetition, leading to his skipper exclaiming: "Yes!"

The two then cannot help but burst into laughter as the goalkeeper gets up from the machine. Fernandes shared the 12-second reel on his Instagram story, captioning it "Puuuuuuush" and tagging his teammate before punctuating the post with a flexed biceps emoji.
Bayindir reposted the story, too, adding a crying laughing emoji and a red heart. The two have shown their closeness this summer with a limited number of players at Carrington.

When they returned to training together, Bayindir shared a photo of him embracing Fernandes inside the gym and adding the caption: "My Hermano." Translating the comment from Spanish, Fernandes shared the post on his story while replying: "Brother".
Both will hope the work they have put in over the last week means they are in contention to play in the Community Shield this weekend against Manchester City.

headline: Man United Matthijs de Ligt transfer claim made as Arsenal 'talks' held over striker agreement

headline: Man United 'remain interested' in Ivan Toney transfer with price tag set
body: Manchester United are reportedly still interested in signing Brentford striker Ivan Toney this summer.

The 28-year-old has been a standout star for the Bees since joining the club from Peterborough United in 2020. Toney's goals have propelled Brentford to the Premier League and in 2022/23 the forward became hot property when he scored 20 goals in 33 Premier League appearances.

However, his momentum took a turn for the worst last season when he was banned by the FA over gambling offences. He returned to the Brentford squad in January and in preparation for his return stressed he wanted a move to a 'bigger club' in the summer.

Toney would go on to score four goals in his first five Premier League appearances back from suspension but only managed one assist, against United, in the remainder of the season. Such a drop off in form has dampened a desire to sign Toney this summer.

While he looked lively during the European Championships, few feel he is worth the original price tag of £100m that Thomas Frank placed on him. As the summer transfer window winds down, no 'bigger clubs' have come in for Toney and his price tag has been slashed as a consequence.

According to Forbes, this could soon be about to change though as they claim United 'remain interested' in the striker. It is thought this interest stems from the injury Rasmus Hojlund suffered during the pre-season tour of the United States.

The report adds that United would be looking at paying approximately £40m should they wish to bring Toney to Old Trafford. With money tight though, it is unclear whether Ineos would green light this move considering he is 28.

headline: Manchester United can get FFP boost at a perfect time for Sir Jim Ratcliffe
body: Manchester United could be reaping the awards in more ways than one for work done in the club’s academy over the past few years.

Head of academy Nick Cox has been praised for his work with the youth teams since being appointed into the role in the summer of 2019. The former Watford and Sheffield United man has been credited with making massive improvements in the academy, and that is now filtering into the first team.

After impressing Erik ten Hag this time last year during pre-season, midfielder Kobbie Mainoo went onto play a key role in the season. His performances earned him a call up to the England team for Euro 2024.

The 19-year-old made a total of 32 first team appearances for United in all competitions last season, scoring five goals. He was hailed for his performance in the FA Cup final against Man City as United came out as 2-1 winners.

History could potentially repeat itself again this year with both Toby Collyer and Harry Amass impressing during pre-season so far. Both players started Sunday’s 3-0 loss against Liverpool, with Amass also being selected for the 3-2 win over Real Betis as well as the friendly vs Arsenal.

Ten Hag has shown with Mainoo that he is not afraid of putting young players in if they impress. That’s a good sign for both Collyer and Amass ahead of the new season, but their development is good news for United, even if they don’t break into the first team.

Their performances mean that clubs will be willing to pay good money if they are sold now or in the future. The fact that they are both academy graduates means that any fee made will go down as pure profit on the club’s accounts.

If that is the case, then it will be a big boost for United given the Premier League’s Profitability and Sustainability Rules (PSRs). Any pure profit made will also come at a time when United need it the most, given the club's recent record on player sales and the money needed for both the new stadium and for incoming transfers.

For United it’s win-win in terms of the improvement in the academy. The club either produces players who can make their way into the first team and reduce the need for incoming transfers, or they can sell for pure profit to boost their finances.

headline: Manchester United might start 17-year-old against Man City after 'aggressive' comment
body: How does it feel to play for Manchester United in front of thousands of fans at just 17 years old?
Just ask Harry Amass, who started against Arsenal, Real Betis and Liverpool on tour in the USA.

"I enjoy it, man," he said. "In front of the crowds, playing with the best players, I’m enjoying it. You’ve just got to show your aggressive side. You might be young, smaller than the opponent, but you have to show you are aggressive and don’t back down. Then you can have a good game."
Amass spoke to Manchester-based reporters in the mixed zone in the Snapdragon Stadium last week and a start against Liverpool in Columbia followed that conversation.

The youngster was asked about a potential start in the Community Shield against Manchester City and said: "No conversations have been had yet, but this pre-season is a chance to prove that if I am picked I can do it. Obviously we’ll see what happens when Luke [Shaw] and Tyrell [Malacia] come back.

"My intention is to play first-team football at this club. I think if the opportunity comes, I’ve got to take it with both hands, it could change my career. I am just waiting for that moment, I am ready."
Luke Shaw started for England in the final of the European Championship against Spain and has been given an extended break, while Tyrell Malacia is still recovering from injury.
Malacia last played a competitive fixture for the Netherlands in June last year and has faced a prolonged period on the sidelines due to a knee injury, which required two rounds of surgery.
The 24-year-old is expected to be available again in two months, which opens the door for Amass, and the London-born full-back intends to capitalise on the opportunity.
After just one year at United, Amass has already drawn comparisons to Shaw, who swapped the South for the North himself when he was a teenager. "It is a good comparison," he said.
"In my opinion, [Shaw is] one of the best left-backs in the Premier League, if not the best for a long time. So I am not gonna complain at the comparisons!"

United thought Shaw had the quality to play at Old Trafford for 10 years when he was signed from Southampton in 2014 and they recognised similar potential in Amass when he was signed from Watford last summer, a move that was considered a coup given the interest from other clubs.

Amass was persuaded to sign for United and hasn't looked back. He was tremendous for the Under-18s last season, playing a key role in a supremely talented team that won a treble, and is now on the cusp of making his senior debut after delivering mature pre-season performances.

Anyone who has watched Amass will understand there can be no concerns about his ability, talent or mentality. He is a technically exceptional, modern-day full-back, but the only question mark against the youngster was whether he was physical enough for senior football.
Amass is diminutive but proved himself on the pre-season tour. His 'aggression' compensates for his lack of stature and he got the better of Mohamed Salah at the weekend.
Malacia won't be involved in the squad for the Community Shield against City on Saturday and Shaw won't have the fitness to play 90 minutes at Wembley.

Amass is almost guaranteed to be involved in some capacity and that will highlight his impressive progress in the space of just a few months, as the youngster only got close to the pitch when he warmed up on the sidelines when he was last at Wembley for the FA Cup semi-final.

Erik ten Hag named Amass, Ethan Wheatley, Habeeb Ogunneye and Louis Jackson on a handful of benches at the end of last season due to the injury crisis and any observers would have noticed how slight they looked, which is normal at their age, in the pre-match warm-ups.
However, what Amass lacks in physicality, he makes up for in character, aggression and talent, so it wouldn't be a surprise to see him start against City in the Community Shield.

headline: 'I've got to take it' - the three Manchester United youngsters set for first team squad roles
body: Joe Hugill was left in the cold at Wigan, Habeeb Ogunneye warmed the bench for nine games, Toby Collyer was an unused substitute on eight occasions and Harry Amass kicked his heels on seven matchdays.

In the end, Ethan Wheatley had the privilege of becoming Manchester United's 250th academy graduate. Wheatley had been on the bench for only two games before he was summoned to replace Rasmus Hojlund for a late cameo against Sheffield United.
"Quite a few of us wanted it and we had a bit of banter about it!" Wheatley says of the 250 milestone. He is stood with Amass and Collyer, both smiling ruefully in the Snapdragon Stadium mixed zone.
Southerners Collyer and Amass are doing their utmost to extend the number to 251 as soon as possible. United expect Collyer, Amass and Wheatley to remain with the squad beyond the transfer window.

Collyer, 20, has started in three of United's four pre-season games and strapped on the captain's armband for the second half against Rosenborg. The 17-year-old Amass has lined up in both tour games in the United States.

Left back Amass followed up his invaluable 45 minutes against Arsenal in Los Angeles, where he was blindsided by Gabriel Jesus for the equalising goal, with a complete performance against Real Betis in San Diego. He capped it with an assist for Amad and drew approval from the crowd with his tenacious tackling.

"I enjoy it, man," the Londoner says. "In front of the crowds, playing with the best players, I’m enjoying it. You’ve just got to show your aggressive side, you might be young, smaller than the opponent, but you have to show you are aggressive and don’t back down. Then you can have a good game."

Amass only joined the United academy from Watford last year. Such was his importance during the run-in last season, Erik ten Hag checked on his well-being in the Carrington canteen when the academy squad returned from their title-clinching win at Wolves in April.

Luke Shaw only played 15 times for United last term and Tyrell Malacia's absence from club football is nearing 15 months. Amass could conceivably start the Community Shield against Manchester City on Saturday.

"No conversations have been had yet," he admits, "but this pre-season is a chance to prove that if I am picked I can do it. Obviously we’ll see what happens when Luke and Tyrell come back. My intention is to play first team football at this club.
"I think if the opportunity comes, I’ve got to take it with both hands, it could change my career. I am just waiting for that moment, I am ready."

Diminutive, fleet-footed and attack-minded, there are obvious parallels with the great Barcelona and Spain left back Jordi Alba. Shaw is another Cockney left back who has settled in Manchester for a decade.

Amass approves of that comparison. "It is a good comparison. In my opinion one of the best left-backs in the Premier League, if not the best for a long time. So I am not gonna complain about the comparison!"

"We have to make progress," Ten Hag said on Amass. "But we all see here a potential where we have seen in previous years, for instance two years ago, Garnacho last season. We had it during last season with Kobbie, but he (Amass) is not that far now at this moment. But if we train him well, if we coach him well, then in three months it's possible that he can be on that point.

"But in this moment he needs to catch up and he has to develop some skills already to play for Manchester United, competing for the highest positions in the league. But with big talent it can go up very quickly and that is very interesting to see if he is capable of doing this."

Collyer, signed from Brighton as an 18-year-old two years ago, trained under Ten Hag as early as September 2022. He is one of only three academy players whose contract signing Ten Hag insisted on attending. The other two were Alejandro Garnacho and Kobbie Mainoo.

"I think it's a massive boost," Collyer says of Ten Hag's attendance for his signing ceremony. "It shows obviously he rates me as a player. Just onwards and upwards really, just got to give my best every day and see what happens."

Collyer came on for half-an-hour at the Snapdragon Stadium and thwarted Betis twice in injury time with valiant interventions. He has acquitted himself impressively and United need to bring down the average age of their midfield department.

"When you're on the bench I think it's really valuable just to be in and around it, experience what it's like on a matchday," Collyer explains. "In the changing room, on the bench, with a crowd, getting used to it. Now I've managed to get quite a lot of minutes in pre-season, so I'm happy.

"I'd say with me, a lot of my work is off the ball as well. Predominantly, I'm a really busy player, I like to get about the pitch and an area of my game I'd like to improve on is in possession. So I think the only way you're going to get better is by demanding the ball, getting on it and not backing away from situations when you could."

Ten Hag made a beeline for Mainoo after United's League Cup victory last year and back at Wembley 15 months later, did likewise with Collyer after United won the FA Cup. "He just said take it all in, enjoy myself and keep working hard and you never know what can happen," Collyer reveals.
"He's a really good guy, the manager. With everyone, he tells you what he wants from each player, he tries his best to help you out, as well as with the other coaching staff as well.
"At the end of the day, they do everything for us and we have to put it out on the pitch and give everything for them."

Stockport-born Wheatley was one of a handful of positives from the listless defeat to Rosenborg last month. He can expect to continue training with the first team amid Rasmus Hojlund's six-week absence with a hamstring strain.

"I'm just taking everything as it comes, to be honest," he cautions. "Obviously, I had a little taste of it last season. This season, I just want to keep my head down, keep developing as a player and keep impressing, so hopefully get more chances.

"The club, its history is of bringing through loads of academy players, the likes of Kobbie, playing with us less than a year ago and breaking into the first team, inspires us and motivates us. Because we know the pathway is there. If we impress, get the chances that will be given at this club we'll take them."

Ruud van Nistelrooy has not rejoined United as a striker coach but Wheatley, born in the same year that Van Nistelrooy left United, is picking his brains. "I think especially since Ruud came in, obviously he was a top striker, he was probably one of the best strikers we've had at the club.
"As soon as he came in I've been trying to take tips off him to help develop my game."

headline: Two players can save Man United millions to create Sir Jim Ratcliffe dream transfer scenario
body: Manchester United have a number of areas that need to be improved, but the club selected three priority areas this summer.

A striker and a centre-back have arrived, while it is thought that Erik ten Hag is closing in on a new midfielder, Manuel Ugarte. While Leny Yoro’s three-month setback could push United into another centre-half signing this window, other positions may need some attention.

One of those is left-back, given how injuries decimated options there last season. Luke Shaw is back to fitness but only played 15 matches last term due to issues and is yet to go through a full season at United without injury.

Meanwhile, Tyrell Malacia is not expected to return until October, having not played in more than a year due to setbacks in his rehabilitation from serious surgery. Sergio Reguilon was acquired on loan last deadline day but returned to Tottenham in January after Ten Hag ended his stay early, with Shaw and Malacia both expected back soon. That never happened.

As a result, Diogo Dalot, Aaron Wan-Bissaka and even Victor Lindelof had to cover in the role with full-back options stretched. Sorting another loan this summer to cover for Malacia would be sensible.

But meanwhile, academy recruit Harry Amass has impressed so far in pre-season, most notably against Real Betis. The 17-year-old joined from Watford last August with big hopes for the future, and the first fruits of his potential are starting to show.

A few first-team stints this coming season followed by consistent progress, and United might not need to find a new left-back when Shaw’s contract runs out in 2027, saving a good few million. For now, third-choice at United is an ample status, and the reality is that the team might still need more experienced cover at left-back via a loanee until Malacia returns.

Another area of debate is the right-wing position. On paper, United have a number of options there, with Antony, Jadon Sancho and Marcus Rashford able to play in the role, Alejandro Garnacho too, albeit to limited effect.

In reality, the spot has hardly been nailed down in Ten Hag’s tenure, with Antony underwhelming his £85m price tag, Rashford preferring the left flank far more, and Sancho falling out with the manager, a feud that has now been quashed.

There has been good reason to suggest that the right wing needs a new addition, but United need not bother. Amad can save United a good few quid in the short term with his assets from the right, as shown against Real Betis.

His breakaway goal against Liverpool in last season’s FA Cup tie showed the raw talent he has, something that former Sunderland boss Tony Mowbray was never shy to underline during Amad’s 14-goal loan spell at the Black Cats two seasons ago.
Amad has now scored twice in pre-season, for what that is worth. His goal against Rangers might have felt sweet given his torrid former prior loan spell in Scotland.

But it was against Real Betis that he showed what he can do when he has minutes under his belt, scoring United’s second of the game after winning a penalty for their first. After recovering from a long-term injury in time for the second half of the season, Amad only managed to start the final three league games.

headline: Alexander Isak comparison, Arsenal fury - Man United sent exciting Chido Martin-Obi verdict
body: Manchester United are closing in on the signing of promising young talent Chido Martin-Obi after the youngster turned down a new contract at Premier League rivals Arsenal. The Gunners are said to have pulled out all the stops to tie the 16-year-old down to fresh terms, but it's United who look set to win the race for the Denmark-born striker.

Obi-Martin, who scored 29 goals in 17 league matches for Arsenal's Under-18s last year, went from strength to strength last season, notably scoring 10 goals in a single game against Liverpool. It's understood United's head of the academy, Nick Cox, and the head of academy recruitment, Luke Fedorenko, are the main driving forces behind the deal.

Once the i's have been dotted and the t's crossed, it will be a significant coup for United's youth set-up which has been undergoing a renaissance after a period of underachieving and Cox's appointment as head of academy in 2019 was a key moment.

The Manchester Evening News spoke with football.london's chief Arsenal writer Kaya Kaynak for an insight into Martin-Obi, his understanding of the deal and what sort of player he is ahead of his arrival in Manchester.

Kaya Kaynak: "It's a bit hard to say as he's still so young, but one thing he seems to be very good at is scoring goals. He's quite a bit taller than most others around his age group right now and looks stylistically a bit similar to Alexander Isak with his languid running and technical ability."
KK: "Arsenal were really keen to keep him. They pulled out all the stops and were confident of doing so after keeping other young talents like Ethan Nwaneri and Myles Lewis-Skelly in recent years.
"However, they do feel they offered all they were willing to offer. With that in mind, there's a feeling of acceptance at the decision Chido has decided to take."

KK: "Any player who scores as many goals as Chido did at such a young age is going to be thought of very highly. It's probably fair to say was viewed as one of the top three or four prospects right now.

"Arsenal are constantly using internal analytics to assess the trajectory of their players and he did look to be a promising talent. At the same time though, it's so hard to tell at 16 and many were intrigued to see how he would have coped at a higher age level."
KK: "I'd say so. There's clearly a high-potential player in there. He's someone who can score lots of goals and that's not easy to find.
"The big test for him will be seeing how he steps up through the age groups. If he manages that though, United have a real player on their hands."
KK: "I think the fact that he was in such high demand this summer tells you what a good player he is. He was wanted by clubs across Europe as well as in England."

headline: Mary Earps takes subtle swipe at Manchester United after PSG move
body: England goalkeeper Mary Earps says she is hoping to add "a few more trophies to the cabinet" after leaving Manchester United to join Paris Saint-Germain (PSG).

Earps joined the Reds in 2019 and helped the club win the FA Cup last year. However, the shot-stopper opted to embark on a new chapter when her contract expired in June after a disappointing Women's Super League (WSL) campaign saw United finished fifth last term - 21 points worse off than in the previous campaign.

Despite being linked with a move to Arsenal, Earps chose to join PSG, who have qualified for the Women's Champions League for six consecutive seasons. Speaking on the latest episode of the BBC's Tooney & Russo Show, Earps said she has established some "great relationships" in Manchester, but her decision to leave was fueled by "the opportunity to play for a great team in top competitions" and be "in a position to win silverware".

"It's like an itch you can never scratch enough,” Earps said. And the 31-year-old's former United teammate Ella Toone, who also plays alongside Earps for the Lionesses, was full of praise for the goalkeeper.
"She deserves everything," said Toone. "Mary's dream - and it always has been - is to play at the highest level, play in the Champions League and that's what she's done."

Earps is not the only player to have left United this summer, with captain Katie Zelem and forward Lucia Garcia also having departed. Reflecting last month on her decision to move overseas, Earps wrote on Instagram: "The club is about to undergo a period of transition, and unfortunately I don’t feel it aligns with the timing of where I’m at in my career, therefore I think now is the right time to make a change and embark on a new challenge."

headline: Manchester United sign Sweden defender in record-breaking transfer
body: Manchester United have confirmed the signing of highly-rated Sweden international Anna Sandberg on three-year deal, with the option of a further year.

The defender joins the Reds from BK Hacken, where she had been playing since July 2022, gaining Champions League experience with the Damallsvenskan side. On the international stage, Sandberg was part of the Sweden squad that finished third at the 2023 FIFA Women’s World Cup.

She joins for what will be a record transfer fee for a Swedish women’s player, surpassing the £150,000 Everton paid to Rosengard for Hanna Bennison in 2021. The 21-year-old full-back is United's fourth signing of the summer, following the arrivals of Dominique Janssen, Elisabeth Terland and Melvine Malard.
“I’m very happy and grateful to sign for this big club, Manchester United," Sandberg said. "I hope I can help our team with my qualities and deliver many winning moments for our fantastic fans.”

Manager Marc Skinner added: “We are delighted to have Anna join our Manchester United family. She is a talented young player, who already has a wealth of international and Champions League experience. We look forward to seeing her develop further in red.”

United finished fifth in the Women's Super League (WSL) last season and won the Women's FA Cup. They will get their 2024/25 campaign underway against West Ham United at Old Trafford on the weekend of September 21/22.

headline: Man United task clear as next England 'superstar' pens emotional Tottenham goodbye
body: As Manchester United set to work dismantling Tottenham Hotspur in the Women's FA Cup final, there was one player inside Wembley Stadium whose loyalties were split.

Grace Clinton, who joined United from Everton in 2022, had spent the season on loan at Spurs and was therefore ineligible to feature against her parent club. Her absence was a huge blow for Robert Vilahamn's side, who ultimately fell to a 4-0 defeat in north-west London as the Reds romped to their first major piece of silverware.

Clinton had been a revelation during her season-long stint at Brisbane Road, completing a clean sweep of Tottenham's Player of the Season awards and breaking into the senior Lionesses squad. "She will be the next superstar in this country if you ask me," Vilahamn said after the midfielder's impressive start to life on loan. "I think she's brilliant and has the potential to be so good."

Clinton form was so good, in fact, that Tottenham were keen to make her stay in the capital permanent. “She cannot stay because she’s not a part of us next year," Vilahamn told The Athletic in April. "But if you ask me if I want to buy her, there would be a high potential I want to do that."

The 21-year-old - who also excelled on loan at Championship side Bristol City in 2022/23 - seemed to relish her time at Spurs, forging a close friendship with teammate Celin Bizet and flourishing under the watchful eye of Vilahamn. “Confidence for me comes from the manager, and both Robert and (England boss) Sarina (Wiegman) have given me so much of that this season,” Clinton told the MEN earlier this year.
“This season I’ve just been filled with confidence and I think you can see that on the pitch. That freedom and confidence from them has allowed me to go and express myself.”

This week, however, seemed to draw a definite line under Clinton's Tottenham adventure, with the midfielder taking to social media to pen an emotional farewell to the Lilywhites. "This past year was by far my happiest season of football," she wrote on Instagram.

"I loved every minute at this club and I’ve made friends for life along the way. I’m so beyond grateful to the staff and my teammates for making this club so special to be a part of. Most importantly thank you to our fans for your unbelievable support this past year, you truly helped us make history and those are moments I will cherish with me."

While part of Clinton's heart might always belong to Spurs, her focus will now turn to transforming United into a consistent force in the Women's Super League (WSL), with the former Everton prodigy set to return to Leigh Sports Village as Marc Skinner's side ramp up their pre-season preparations. Despite beating Tottenham to the FA Cup trophy last term, the Reds faltered in the top flight, finishing in fifth place and winning just 10 of their league games.

In spite of United's turbulent campaign, manager Skinner was somewhat controversially awarded a one-year contract extension by the club's hierarchy and the 41-year-old will surely now be delighted to have Clinton to call upon as he bids to turn the Reds' WSL fortunes around.

Though he has always been unequivocal in his stance on the 21-year-old, insisting that her long-term future lies in Manchester, her return will be a huge boost for Skinner, particularly considering the club have parted company with midfield duo Katie Zelem and Irene Guerrero this summer.
"All I hear is Tottenham want to keep Grace, of course they want to keep Grace," the United boss said when quizzed on the club's plans for Clinton back in May. "She's a fantastic player.

"We don't get the credit that we identified her qualities at Everton, we brought her to Manchester United, gave her six months, sent her on loan at Bristol – she got experience. She then went on loan to Tottenham to get more experience. I don't think people recognise that – there is a plan for each individual we bring into the club.
"With Grace, it's absolutely worked. I want to bring her back to the club and be part of what we're doing because I think she has a huge say in how we'll play."

Certainly, Clinton returns to United a much more well-rounded player than when she left, having gained valuable experience on both the domestic and international stage. The midfielder won her first senior cap for the Lionesses against Austria in February and took just 19 minutes to crown her eye-catching debut with a goal.

"She plays like a natural," Wiegman said after the game. "She wants to have the ball. She picks up the things we talk about very quickly and that's what you see on the pitch too. She just goes out there and plays."
Clinton has won a further two caps over the past five months and is surely destined for many more. But it is not only on the pitch where the youngster has learnt some valuable lessons of late.

“Grace is a great girl,” Manchester City and England defender Alex Greenwood told the MEN in April. “You see her about and she's always wanting to ask questions, learn from everyone, and she's a really confident girl as well. She believes in herself and she always wants to improve, and I love that about Grace.

“She was doing a press conference and so she came up to me and Lucy (Bronze) and said: ‘What can’t I say?’ That’s just an innocent question and that’s not even about football but it’s stuff that comes hand-in-hand now with playing for the Lionesses.
“At dinner she asks questions like ‘What do you eat Al?’ I remember her first camp, we were on a walk before the game and I said: ‘Grace, you haven’t shut up this whole walk’...but it’s nice.”

While it's clear Clinton still has plenty to learn - both on and off the pitch - her return could spell very good news for United as they look to bounce back from the disappointment of last season. Her time at Spurs may have played a vital role in shaping her career to date but it is the Reds who must now help England's "next superstar" fulfil her true potential.

headline: Man United make Old Trafford decision as plan for Man City showdown revealed
body: Manchester United have confirmed they will play three Women's Super League (WSL) matches at Old Trafford next season, including a potentially decisive Manchester derby in May.

The Reds play the majority of their home games at Leigh Sports Village, the home of rugby league side Leigh Leopards. However, Marc Skinner's side did play twice at the Theatre of Dreams last term and are now set to add a further game to their Old Trafford allocation in 2024/25.

United will face West Ham United at the stadium on the opening weekend of the campaign (September 21/22) before hosting newly-promoted Crystal Palace on the weekend of February 15/16. The Reds will then welcome local rivals Manchester City to Old Trafford on May 3/4 in a game that could have a bearing on the destination of the WSL title.

City did the double over United last season, including a 3-1 win at the Theatre of Dreams in November, and finished 20 points above Skinner's side, pushing champions Chelsea all the way in the title race. The Reds, who finished in fifth place, will hope for a very different outcome next term as they seek to add more silverware to their Women's FA Cup trophy.
"It’s always such a pleasure to play at Old Trafford and the entire squad are really looking forward to returning there for our season opener against West Ham," said manager Skinner.

“To then also be back to face Crystal Palace mid-season and then close our WSL campaign against Manchester City is really something for all our great fans to be excited for - and we cannot wait for them all to pack the stands for all three games.”

United have introduced the Old Trafford Bundle - entitling fans to tickets to all three matches for a reduced price - to encourage as many people as possible to show their support for the women's team. The record attendance for a United Women's game is currently the 43,615 set in that Manchester derby defeat eight months ago.

An adult match ticket bundle is priced at £30, with reduced rates for men's Season Ticket holders, juniors and United members. Fans can also purchase United Women season tickets which include entry to all games the team play, both at Leigh Sports Village and Old Trafford.
